question: Knowing that I could be assassinated at any moment, I feel it's important that some people should understand my thoughts. I think that-- I wish I had time to explain everything I did. Almost everything that was done was done with an eye on the gay movement. Hey. I'm Harvey.
answer: Okay, Harvey...

question: Today's my birthday. No, today is actually my birthday. Well, tonight. At midnight.
answer: Really?

question: And, believe it or not, I don't have any plans. People took me out after work...
answer: Work? So, that would be... Let me guess. Ma Bell or AT&T.

question: The Great American Insurance Company. I'm part of the big, evil, corporate establishment that, let me guess, you think is the cause of every evil thing in the world from Vietnam to diaper rash.
answer: You left out bad breath. Falling for it, Harvey covers his mouth. Scott laughs. They both smile, realizing they share a wry sense of humor. A TRAIN IS COMING, Harvey has to work fast.

question: So... You're not going to let me celebrate my birthday all by myself are you?
answer: Listen, Harvey, you're kind of cute for a suit... But I don't do guys over forty.

question: Well then, I'm in luck.
answer: How's that?

question: Because I'm still thirty-nine... And it's only eleven-fifteen. Where are you from?
answer: Jackson, Mississippi.

question: Well, this isn't Jackson, but you still can't respond to every strange man you meet on a subway platform. It's too dangerous.
answer: Now you tell me.

question: There's nothing tougher than a New York City cop. They're arrogant, and they're everywhere. I'll show you the cruising spots, if you want, if you promise you'll be careful... little Scottie-san.
answer: Are you on uppers or what?

question: No. This is just... plain old me.
answer: You're afraid of the cops?

question: I'm just discreet. I know a lot of people here. If they found out, I could lose my job.
answer: Oh. You're one of "those." I think you need a change of scenery. New friends.

question: I need a change.
answer: You're forty now.

question: Forty years old and I haven't done a thing I'm proud of.
answer: You keep eating like this and you'll be a fat ass by fifty.

question: No. Don't you worry. I won't make it to fifty. Scott distracts him, playful, like a newlywed at a wedding, he rubs a slice of pie in Harvey's face. Harvey reacts. Wipes the pie from his eye, and tackles his young, frisky new lover. They kiss. The mess getting everywhere. Harvey brushes it out of Scott's hair. (an idea, half-jokingly,
answer: Where to?

question: In those days, San Francisco was the place where everyone wanted to go... To drop out... To fall in love... But by 1972, The Haight was boarded up. Crime-filled. Drug-filled. The new place for us refugees was this run down Irish Catholic neighborhood in Eureka Valley. Six blocks square... The Castro.
answer: I cashed my last unemployment check yesterday...

question: Well, I hope you did something useful with it.
answer: I bought an ounce of pot. I was just wondering if you had any plans, or thoughts... About us doing something to, you know, bring in an income.

question: Don't move. Harvey straddles Scott. He begins SNAPPING PHOTOS of him.
answer: I suppose I can wait tables.

question: One with very little overhead. Not too much work... A little one, just like Morris and Minnie Milk of Woodmere, New York... Just a little to the left... The old liquor store owner from earlier, MCCONNELLY, crosses the street to watch. Harvey gives him a warm welcome: Hello there. I'm Harvey Milk.
answer: You're the new renters?

question: Yes. Welcome to Castro Camera. I want to join the, um... What is it? The Eureka Valley Merchant's Association. I want to help in any way possible. I'm no interloper. A Jew perhaps, but I hope you'll forgive that. McConnelly looks from Harvey to Scott in the window.
answer: I don't think your application will be approved, Mr. Milk. This is a family neighborhood. Your kind are far more welcome on Haight street.

question: What "kind" do you mean, sir?
answer: The Merchant's Association will have the police pull your license if you open your doors.

question: Thanks for the warm welcome to the neighborhood!
answer: We pay taxes you know! Harvey grabs Scott's hand... keeps him from heating up, from pouncing. It's not the time for them to bite yet.

question: We'll form our own business association! Start with the gay- owned businesses... We'll take down the addresses of every customer that comes in for a roll of film. We'll ask them what they want to see done here... what they want changed... We'll get money rolling into this neighborhood. Revitalize it...
answer: Can I come in now?

question: One more minute! I'll go to the neighborhood banks. They must have some gay customers.
answer: Harvey. What's with all this political activist crap? I thought you were a goddamn Republican. Harvey walks into the small dining room holding two plates of food. He sets them out on a small dining room table, still rambling on to Scott in the bedroom.

question: I'm a businessman, Scott. I think businesses ought to treat their customers right. Even their gay customers. For God's sake, this is San Francisco!
answer: Harvey. It's just like every other city in this country. People hate us. Big surprise.

question: We should have at least one block in one city right? Start there and take over the neighborhood. Okay, you can come in now! Scott heads toward the kitchen. The table is LAID OUT with a home-cooked meal, CANDLES and a huge bouquet of FLOWERS.
answer: Wow. This is--

question: Welcome. What can we do for you?
answer: Hi, I'm Allan Baird. Teamsters representative, and Director of the Coors beer boycott in California.

question: Everyone, this is Allan Baird. He's a very big deal, so behave yourselves.
answer: I was told you were like the Mayor of the Castro, said you organized the CVA, you might know some people in the bars.

question: I do have friends in awfully low places, but just so you know, it's not official yet.
answer: What's that?

question: The Mayor part. I've considered gathering an army of queers to march up to City Hall and secede, but so far the young gays seem more interested in jeeps and jeans. But if I could be of any use, I'm all ears!
answer: We can't get Coors to go union. These guys are like me, they can't be out of work too long. Harvey pulls Allan aside, away from the audience, easing his nerves. It's Harvey at his best.

question: I'm just curious. Are we your first stop or your last?
answer: It's been a tough one, Mr. Milk.

question: Well, you seem to have noticed that my kind of people drink a lot of beer. If we're going to fast for your sake, I think we should get to deliver some of it when you win this fight, don't you? And allies. I'll have Coors out of every bar in the Castro by the end of the week. Deal?
answer: Thank you Mr. Milk.

question: No more Coors beer. It's gotta come out of every bar. Gay and straight.
answer: What's he giving you?

question: Nothing for me. That's a convert.
answer: A convert to what?

question: ...if we had someone in the government who saw things the way we see them, the way the black community has black leaders who look out for their interests--
answer: You're gonna run for Supervisor, is that the idea?

question: Politics is theater. It doesn't matter if you win. You make a statement. You say, "I'm here, pay attention to me."
answer: Harvey, you do that every time you cross the street.

question: Coors looks like it might cave. The union boys will owe me. Imagine if we get their vote... It'll be fun!
answer: Fun? Harvey starts kissing him all over.

question: We'll make it a spectacle. A week ago, Police officers came into our area with covered up badges and sent fourteen of our people to the hospitals, and to jail. The charges, "Blocking a Sidewalk." Like a round girl at a boxing match, Scott parades around a blown up PHOTO from his shopping cart --Let us have our tax money go for our protection and not our persecution. Worry about gun control and not marijuana control. School supplies, seniors, not what books I read-- Scott displays an old "Muscle Boys" magazine. Harvey does a well timed take. A few hoots from the eclectic crowd. My fellow degenerates, I would like to announce my candidacy for San Francisco City Supervisor! Scott unfurls three hand made "MILK FOR CITY SUPERVISOR" banners that lap over the sides of the shopping cart. Public dental care for retired people... Legalize pot, vote Milk. Harvey is distracted. A young, long haired CLEVE JONES passes. At 18, he looks 15. Harvey tries for his attention: Hey, I like the way your pants fit... Where are you from, kid? Where's home?
answer: Phoenix.

question: I'm Harvey Milk. I'm running for Supervisor. What's your name?
answer: Cleve... Jones.

question: Well Mr. Jones, we should walk up to my camera shop and register you.
answer: Fuck that. Elections of any kind are a bourgeois affectation.

question: Is that right? Do you trick up on Polk Street?
answer: If I need the cash... But I'm selective about my clients.

question: Tell me one thing before you get back to work then. What was it like to be a little queer in Phoenix?
answer: I faked a lung disease to get out of PE. So what? What are you, some kind of street shrink?

question: Sometimes. But what I'm saying is, Phoenix can change. But we have to start with our street
answer: Well, good luck with all that.

question: You know what I think, Cleve Jones?
answer: That you're gonna get somewhere if you keep talking?

question: No. That you need to do what you're good at. Be a prick. Fight City Hall. Fight the cops. Fight the people who made you come here to do what you do.
answer: Sorry old man, I'm leaving for Spain tomorrow. Europe. Got all the cash I need in my back pocket. A GROUP OF CLEVE'S FRIENDS shout at him to join them. Harvey watches him dart across the street to his friends.

question: I didn't come out until very late in life. There was nobody to-- --look up to, no hope for a better life. Those that did were outcast... arrested.. suicide. And the young ones, who did escape home... and who arrive in San Francisco, and then what...
answer: The fruit was walking home with his trick when they were jumped. REVEAL Name's Robert Hillsborough. Did you know him?

question: He used to come into my shop. Are there any witnesses?
answer: Just the "trick." Jerry Taylor.

question: Jerry wasn't a trick. They were lovers.
answer: Call it what you will. He's our only witness and he says he can't identify the attackers.

question: There'd be a dozen witnesses if they thought you boys had any real interest in keeping them safe.
answer: You're the Mayor of Castro Street now, right Harvey? You really wanna help? Get your people to show some discretion on the streets, huh? HARVEY'S POV

question: Who cares about those old queens? Scott is laying down on THE BIG RED COUCH.
answer: Why isn't my campaign manager leading the meeting?

question: I'm beat, Harvey. I passed out flyers for seven hours straight.
answer: In the bathhouse?

question: People in bathhouses vote. I'm tired. I'm taking a nap. Scott heads up the stairs to their apartment. A CUSTOMER comes in. Danny quickly gathers the REVEALING PHOTOS and puts them back in the envelope.
answer: Just checking the exposure. That a new boyfriend? He's very cute. So who are these so-called "gay leaders?" And who appointed them? And what are you suggesting, Jim, that I'm supposed to go and solicit their endorsement? PAST HARVEY WE SEE A GRANDMOTHERLY VOLUNTEER, THELMA, opening the mail, casually reading a letter, then rising and approaching Harvey. We're down here, on the streets, trying to help people, so where they hell are they?

question: "Harvey Milk will have a dream journey and nightmare to hell, a night of horror. You will be stabbed and have your genitals, cock, balls, prick cut off."
answer: They probably wrote it. Hey, If somebody tries to kill me, I'll get the sympathy vote, right? Could be just the push we need.

question: You think this is funny? Look at it. Reluctantly, Harvey takes the letter from Scott.
answer: It's a complete joke. No rhythm. No humor. It's insulting. CLOSE ON THE LETTER

question: Don't do that.
answer: If you put it away, hide it in a drawer, it'll just get bigger and scarier. Now it's there. We'll see it every day. It can't get us.

question: All this energy... to make yourself a target. And what for? Something we have no chance to win. Harvey wraps his arms around him.
answer: I keep telling you, it's not just about winning. The "top gays" in San Francisco were David Goodstein and his lawyer sidekick Rick Stokes. David was a rich old queen who'd bought the biggest gay magazine, The Advocate. He had it delivered to subscribers in brown paper bags so no-one would know... That's how he lived his life, covered up, discreet. Harvey and Scott are shown to the pool area by a HOUSE BOY. Statues and potted plants and expensive marble. Everything shouts "GOOD TASTE!" Scott strips off his clothes and DIVES INTO THE POOL.

question: I keep telling you, it's not just about winning. The "top gays" in San Francisco were David Goodstein and his lawyer sidekick Rick Stokes. David was a rich old queen who'd bought the biggest gay magazine, The Advocate. He had it delivered to subscribers in brown paper bags so no-one would know... That's how he lived his life, covered up, discreet. Harvey and Scott are shown to the pool area by a HOUSE BOY. Statues and potted plants and expensive marble. Everything shouts "GOOD TASTE!" Scott strips off his clothes and DIVES INTO THE POOL.
answer: I worked for a financial institution. I was very discreet. But someone spotted me at the opera, sitting in a box, next to my lover. And I was fired. That's when I decided to do something. So I bought The Advocate. And I use my money and my influence in quiet ways, to do what I can...

question: Endorsing straight candidates is what you think is best to help us?
answer: Yes, if they're friendly to our cause.

question: But I am running for office. I'm on the ballot. I have the union rank and file, the seniors, and I could use your magazine's endorsement.
answer: Harvey, we're like the Catholic church. We welcome converts, but we don't make them Pope the same day.

question: And why haven't you run?
answer: It's too early for a gay candidate for Supervisor. Especially one from the Castro. It's bad for the community's image. Scott climbs out of the pool and sits at the table, naked and sopping wet.

question: The cops come into our neighborhood and beat us. They turn a blind eye if one of us is murdered.
answer: Then we file a lawsuit against the city. We go to our political allies in City Hall...

question: There are no real gay allies. Yes, our friends may sense our struggle, but they can't feel it. It's not life or death for them. We need our own in office.
answer: You can't demand acceptance overnight.

question: Why not? How can we ask them to respect us if we don't show ourselves some self respect, David.
answer: The more out you make us, the more you incite them. Step back and quiet down.

question: Go back into the closet? Is that what you're saying? Because I know the closet. I lived in it for more years than I care to remember. I don't need your endorsement. I'm not asking anyone for acceptance. I don't have time to ask.
answer: For you, politics is a game, a lark. Like putting on a rock festival or staging a "love-in." You're too old to be a hippie, Harvey Milk! Harvey turns around, ready for a fight.

question: I'm not a candidate, I'm part of a movement. The movement is the candidate. There's a difference. You don't see the difference. But I do.
answer: Thanks for the swim. I'm sorry I pissed in your pool.

question: When the vote came in on election day... out of 32 candidates vying for 6 seats... We came in 10th. Just a handful short of being the first big eared, gay as a three- dollar-bill, cock sucker ever elected to public office. So... I went for it again in '75... with just a few... minor... adjustments.
answer: No. Not cute. The shoes are hideous and I hate your hair. You're not fooling anybody.

question: I'm not gonna let the Pacific Heights biddies write me off again because of a ponytail. I like it. Scott is horrified. Harvey pulls a pair of movie ticket stubs from its inner pocket. Cabaret? For two? Lily, is this from one of my kind?
answer: This isn't sexy, Harvey. Harvey grabs Scott, kisses him. Then playful:

question: Too bad. No more pot, no more bath houses for me and little poo. We ran and we lost the Supervisors race a second time in '75, but with more votes than ever. So in 1976, against everyone's advice, I really pissed off the Democratic political power houses, because I ran against "their boy"-- --Art Agnos, a part of their "Political Machine." And this time we weren't running for City Supervisor. This time it was bigger, California State Assembly. It's a racket. It's 1976 and you still have to be straight, white, Catholic and male to get into the San Francisco police force. It's Racist. Homophobic. You're right, Art. And many are your closest friends. You see, I don't think State Assembly seats should be awarded on the basis of service to the Democrat Machine. Machines operate on oil and grease. They're dirty, dehumanizing, and too often unresponsive to any needs but those of the operator. Tell me Mr. Agnos... right here in the Castro, Robert Hillsbourough was murdered for walking home with his long time partner. Stabbed, fifteen times. The last words he heard were "Faggot, Faggot, Faggot..." And you say you're outraged, but why won't your liberal establishment return our calls? Why won't they bring these murderers to justice? My God, you're handsome up close. I can't tell you how much I'm looking forward to licking you... in the polls.
answer: Harvey. Dinner.

question: If we lose this one, it'll be just me and you again. I promise. Scott nods. That's exactly what he needed to hear. Phoenix? We should go inside. They do. Harvey locks the door behind them.
answer: You staying up with me?

question: The election's tomorrow. I won't sleep... Was he good looking?
answer: No. He was hideous.

question: Hard to tell what's worse. With me, my boyfriends usually find better looking ones to cheat with.
answer: I thought we were gonna spend the rest of our lives together.

question: Guess what, Cleve Jones.
answer: What?

question: You're going to meet the most extraordinary men, the sexiest, brightest, funniest men, and you're going to fall in love with so many of them, and you won't know until the end of your life who your greatest friends were or your greatest love was.
answer: Is that supposed to help?

question: Maybe a little. Or not.
answer: I went to Spain last month... long story. In Barcelona, there was this memorial march for gay people who died under Franco. The police tried to break it up. It started a riot. A bullet ripped through a drag queens scalp, his wig flew off, but he kept fighting. There was blood literally running in the gutter.

question: We could have a revolution here too. But you can't just use the Castro to cruise. You gotta fight.
answer: You think you'll win?

question: Winning isn't my strong suit. Can you assemble a thousand people in an hour?
answer: Yeah, sure.

question: All right, if I run again, you're my man.
Scottie?
answer: I'm sorry sir. I um... I read about you in the paper.

question: I'm sorry. I can't talk right--
answer: Sir, I think I want to kill myself.

question: No. You don't want to do that.
answer: In Minnesota.

question: You saw me in a paper in Minnesota? How'd I look?
answer: My folks are taking me to this place tomorrow. A hospital. To fix me.

question: There's nothing wrong with you. Listen to me. You don't have to hurt yourself, okay? Are you there? Here's what you have to do. Are you listening?
answer: Yes.

question: Get on a bus. Go to the next biggest city. New York, San Francisco, LA, or even Minneapolis. It doesn't matter. Just leave. You won't be alone. There are people out here just like you who will welcome you and love you. You're not sick. You're not wrong. God does not hate you. Just leave.
answer: I can't.

question: Yes. You can. Just get on a bus.
answer: I can't... I can't walk, sir. I'm in a wheelchair... Sir. Are you there? Harvey FORCES HIMSELF TO SOUND CALM...

question: Evelyn Lear's in town, at the Opera house in Tannhauser.
answer: Clearly.

question: What if she strolls into the Castro for a cocktail? Just one more. We can't let Rick Stokes take it.
answer: Let Rick have it. Nobody thinks you're a fraud here, Harvey. You're not in New York, you're not a closet case asshole anymore. People respect you here. Relax for a year. Get us back on our feet.

question: If people are ever going to take me seriously, I have to win this one.
answer: Since when did you care if anyone took you seriously?

question: Anita wants to put us all back in concentration camps. Rick Stokes is too weak to beat her back if she gets to California. I have to be in office to protect us from them.
answer: I can't do another one. I'll be back for my sheets. If you're not here, I'll see you in the shop next week. Scott picks up his box of clothes and starts out of the apartment. Harvey, not meaning a word:

question: If you leave me right now... I can find someone new.
answer: I know. You're a catch. Scott leaves. Harvey is in shock, unable to comprehend the loss. Unable/unwilling to reverse the choice he's made.

question: Just give me whatever's left over in the register at the end of the day. So should I call the Chronicle about getting US an endorsement? No? OFF the group of misfits, considering the addition.
answer: Young lady, you must be confused. This is my night, not Mr. Milk's.

question: No, sir. I'm Harvey's new campaign manager. Anne Kronenberg.
answer: Then you should know this race is for District 5, the Castro, not for all of your lesbian... compadres-- A tough lesbian kisses Anne and stares Rick down as she heads in. Rick looks uncomfortable around all these women.

question: ...Palomino's are my favorite horse. They're smart. They're fast and compact. Do you think I'm more like a Palomino or a Stallion? Jack smiles, out of his mind. Then he sits/falls down into the chair, and slides off. Harvey stands above the passed out young man. A newcomer. A wounded bird. Perfect. My father beat me when he found out... So I came here. I stay in this man's house. But I don't like him.
answer: Shh, it's okay, now. No one's ever going to beat you again. A long, comforting beat between them.

question: I love you.
answer: Do you even remember my name? Harvey.

question: What about Dan White? Did he win? I have to be. That's what I was elected for. I have to be there to open up the dialogue for the sensitivities of all people, all their problems, the problems that effect this city effect all of us. Thank you San Francisco! Thank you! I, Harvey Milk, do solemnly swear that I will support and defend the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of California against all enemies, foreign and domestic; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter and during such time as I hold the office of Supervisor, City and County of San Francisco. Bulbs FLASH. A light rain begins to fall. Umbrellas go up. Anita Bryant said gay people brought the drought to California. Looks to me like it's finally started raining! Cheers. Harvey is emboldened. The name of the game on the Board is six votes to get anything passed. So, like it or not, Dan and I are now in bed together... politically speaking. THE CAMERA REVEALS SCOTT watching the program. He's been up all night.
answer: I've assured Harvey here that my brochure's comments about "social deviants" referred more to junkies than to his people. See, I'm about to have my first child. I have to make sure this city remains a decent place to raise him.

question: How long were you a fireman, Dan?
answer: A couple of years.

question: And before that... You were a police officer? Dan studies Harvey suspiciously... What's his point?
answer: You have something against cops?

question: No. They tend to have something against me. But firefighters. Now those are true heroes... They supported me in the last campaign. I support them fully.
answer: I appreciate it.

question: I meant what I said. I'd like to work together. Dan hesitantly accepts Harvey's handshake. It's a step.
answer: I'll see you at the office, Mr. Milk.

question: What do you think of my new theater?
answer: A bit over the top.

question: What's with the suit?
answer: I got it from a friend. Harvey leads Cleve from the elevator to the grand staircase.

question: Jack?
answer: Welcome home, Harvey! I hope you're hungry. I only know how to cook one thing, but I make it good.

question: Did you... break in?
answer: I asked the boy downstairs to let me in...

question: Danny?
answer: He wouldn't let me in. So I came in this way. Your friends aren't very nice to me.

question: I have a Town Hall meeting tonight, Jack.
answer: You work too hard. I'm sorry about your window. I'll fix it tomorrow. Are you surprised?!

question: You work too hard. I'm sorry about your window. I'll fix it tomorrow. Are you surprised?!
answer: Jack, I have to go. I have an invitation to a party tomorrow. Lots of rich people, politicians. We could get all dressed up... Jack turns up the music, takes Harvey's hands and guides him through a simple dance.

question: So I could be the first lady?
answer: Uh-huh.

question: I watched TV here today. All day. I saw All My Children. They killed Margo. I knew it was going to happen. They try and trick you but it never works.
answer: You always see it coming?

question: What? Killing the blonde? Every time. I'm good with that. I think now the old lady is going to have an affair. Then she'll get killed or married. Always one or the other. Dead or married. Jack starts dancing with Harvey again. It's sweet, intimate.
answer: If I make you a key, you won't break my windows again, right?

question: That's right. The dance lesson is a lovely distraction. Harvey won't be going back to work tonight.
answer: I'm proposing a citywide ordinance. It ensures that a person who already has a job can't be fired for their orientation.

question: I'm proposing a citywide ordinance. It ensures that a person who already has a job can't be fired for their orientation.
answer: I'm not sure my constituents would favor that. Dan looks over to his WIFE and NEWBORN SON.

question: Is anyone else here from the Board?
answer: You're the only one who showed up I think.

question: Were you christened here?
answer: Yes. Right here. Same Parish. My grandma immigrated here when this was an Irish Catholic city. The City of St. Francis... A lot's changed here since then.

question: You're more like one of us now... an outsider.
answer: You're not like most homosexuals, are you, Harvey?

question: Do you know a lot of "homosexuals?"
answer: Say, where do you stand on the Psychiatric Center the City's been pushing into my district?

question: Well, I'd have to study it...
answer: Getting it out of my district was a key piece of my platform. It only attracts arsonist, rapists, all that, you know.

question: Sure, sure. A campaign promise.
answer: A big one.

question: I'd like that, too, Dan. Mary Ann White approaches with their child. It's awkward, as if she's walked in on something intimate.
answer: I'm sorry. Slipped into some shop talk.

question: Excuse me, David? You're right, I know, I was late by twenty minutes. I'm sorry, Jack.
answer: Who were you with? Scott? Some boy?

question: I was at work. Come out, sugar pea.
answer: No. You embarrassed me. I didn't know anyone. These are not good people. I don't want to be here.

question: Then go home, Jack.
answer: No. I'll wait for you. Go away. A tight smile from Harvey as he looks up to Cleve.

question: I thought you were done with politics.
answer: Politics. Not the movement. What the hell was that in there?

question: The movement needs people to be up- front. Why were you fighting me?
answer: You were the biggest closet case alive in New York. You told me and all your boyfriends to keep our traps shut. You were the hypocrite in there.

question: My parents are gone. My brother knows. I'm sure they knew.
answer: I had to listen to your phone calls home to Mom. Hear you deny that I existed. You want to be "normal" as bad as any of us. More than any of us... Those are kids in there. You're asking them to lose their families.

question: If their families won't love them for who they are, who they really are, then they should lose them.
answer: That's fucking insane.

question: Who's he? Do you live together?
answer: Someone I'm seeing. He's good for me. He makes me stay home at nights, out of the bars...

question: I miss you.
answer: Oh, Harvey, don't... What's that about?

question: Can I have a moment with Harvey? Alone, please, Carol? She politely recognizes the tension and gets up. Why are you turning on me like this at the last minute? What did I do?
answer: I didn't have all the details. I'll help you craft a different version that doesn't displace any kids.

question: Harvey, I can't go back to my family and to my folks and to my district without this. Don't do this.
answer: I'm getting a lot of pressure, Dan.

question: You strung me along. And now you're throwing me to the wolves.
answer: You only need one more vote, Dan. There are 5 other Supervisors you could convince besides me. Dan grabs Harvey. It's threatening. A new side of Dan.

question: I'll vote against your Queer Law. I'll get Quentin against it.
answer: It'll still pass. You can't keep alienating yourself here, Dan.

question: I gave you a chance, Harvey. I really did. You blew it. You really blew it. Dan goes, the rage of a scorned adolescent under his suit.
answer: Across the country, a handful of city councils had passed the very first ordinances protecting gay people against discrimination. But Anita Bryant and her right wing Christian fundamentalists were creating and exploiting and fanning a backlash. Now she had referenda to repeal all of these gay rights ordinances. While we were preparing for the battle against Briggs and Prop Six, Anita Bryant was taking her show on the road... sweeping the country. Her next stop was Wichita, Kansas.

question: Hi. We're losing Wichita. Rally tonight. Sundown. Market and Castro. A MULTIPLYING FRAME EFFECT They're moving. I don't know where, but...
answer: Did Jim call the press? Get out there with your camera!

question: Press is covered. But we don't have a permit to march.
answer: When I got Coors out of the bars, the Union gave me this. I want you to have it.

question: What do I do with this?
answer: You're an activist. Take it. March them. March those people up to the front doors of City Hall. When it looks really bad, the city's first gay Supervisor will come out and play peacemaker. We save the city from a riot. We can turn this night into more political power for the cause.

question: I can't do it like you do it.
answer: I won't always be here. Somebody else will have to take over. I need you to be the scary one now.

question: What are you working on, Dan?
answer: If you have something to discuss, you can have your aide make an appointment with my aide.

question: Listen, I know you're disappointed about the Psychiatric Center... What else do you have coming up?
answer: Now you need something from me. You want my me to join in with the Queers on this Prop Six business?

question: We prefer the word "gay," Dan. Just as I'm sure you prefer the word, "Irish-American" to "Mick."
answer: Harvey, our society can't exist without the family, without the church.

question: We're not against those things.
answer: You're not? Can two men reproduce?

question: No. But, we keep trying! C'mon, Dan. You're channeling Anita and Briggs... we can work together. On something...
answer: Okay. You introduce an initiative for Supervisor pay raises.

question: It's a bad time politically. I have an election next year.
answer: You asked for something. Introduce pay raises. I can't take care of my family on our salaries. You don't have that problem, do you? Dan's AIDE steps into the doorway. She seems surprised to see Harvey in Dan's office. Mr. Milk, You'll excuse me, I have a development meeting. Dan goes.

question: I'll take it under consideration. Why don't you get us a drink? A kiss and Jack heads to the bar. Scott approaches.
answer: Don't let Cezar Chavez hear you calling him Taco Bell.

question: He's getting better. He's enrolling in classes on Monday. Scott wipes PIE CREAM from Harvey's jacket.
answer: I remember when your birthdays were a bit less... lavish. More intimate.

question: Who invited you? Anne?
answer: My boyfriend got an invitation. I was his "plus one."

question: Congratulations. It was a tough ticket to get.
answer: Congratulations to you. Looks like you're part of the Machine now. You can do better.

question: When I come home to Jack, I don't have to talk politics or talk intelligently. Or even talk.
answer: You're not so old. You look handsome... Happy 48th. Looks like you're gonna make it to fifty after- all, Mr. Milk. Scott gives Harvey a BIRTHDAY KISS.

question: Sorry I missed the party, Harv...
answer: No problem, Dan. Good to see you.

question: Dog poop?
answer: Yeah.

question: It's good! It's a good one.
answer: Thanks. But it's a real problem.

question: Oh, yeah. I mean, God knows how many problems it causes. All kinds of diseases, birth defects probably, I mean, stuff you can't even... Hey, I got you a little something.
answer: You didn't have to--

question: You didn't have to--
answer: Are you okay, Dan?

question: Oh, what? Yeah, sure. Harvey, I just... I just want to say... Happy Birthday. Dan PUTS HIS ARMS AROUND HARVEY for a sort-of macho but really weird birthday hug. Harvey stiffens, it's such a peculiar moment. Dan steps back, looks him over. I've really learned a lot from watching you, Harvey.
answer: I doubt that.

question: No, I have. You gotta get out there. Get noticed. That's how it works. But, you have an issue. That's your advantage.
answer: It's more than an issue, Dan. Dan. I've had four relationships in my life. Three of those four tried to kill themselves. I know it was my fault they did it. I told them to stay quiet. To hide. Most of my life I've been closeted. That's what living this life is like for most of us. The way things are... This isn't just about our jobs, or any issue, it's our lives we're fighting for. Jack emerges from the bathroom, barely together and leans on Harvey. Dan steps back from Harvey and Jack, his moment alone stolen away.

question: I've learned a lot from you, Harvey. I'm going to get my picture in the papers, too. You'll see. I've got my own issue. That's right. Dan White's Got An Issue!
answer: Come out! Just come on out! DRIVING THE CAR

question: Hi, I'm Harvey Milk. It's quite an honor to meet you, Mr. Briggs.
answer: I'm aware. Sad you're too afraid to fight this out in public, Mr. Milk.

question: No sir. I would love to have a public debate. I'm very interested in the details of your argument.
answer: You know the details. As do the people. Look at the votes across this nation. The "public" is with me.

question: Yes sir, today they are. But with my City's Mayor and the San Francisco press as my witnesses, I'm challenging you to a public debate. John nods, stiff. He can no longer avoid Harvey Milk. He gets back in his limo. Senator, as a Christian it's interesting that you don't seem to understand what Christ was about. He was about accepting people and giving love, not carrying a Bible in one hand and hatred in the other... ...Now all the gay myths have been shattered, all the fears, all the--
answer: Not in my mind they haven't--

question: That's it. In your mind they haven't, and I'm wondering why--
answer: Mr. Milk, we don't allow people who believe in practicing bestiality to teach our children, and the reason we don't is because it is illegal. But it's not illegal to be a homosexual in California.

question: And your law goes even further. Any school employee who even supports a gay person will be fired--
answer: True. But, gay people don't have children of their own. If they don't recruit our children, they'd all die away. That's why they want to be teachers, to encourage our children to join them.

question: How do you teach homosexuality? Like French? I was born of heterosexual parents, I was taught by heterosexual teachers in a fiercely heterosexual society. So then why am I homosexual? And no offense meant, but if it were true that children mimicked their teachers, you'd sure have a helluva lot more nuns running around. The audience eats it up. It feel like "The Harvey Milk Show."
answer: If they're going to lead such an open life of homosexuality that they want a 21-gun salute every time somebody goes by them, those people are going to be in danger of being removed their job.

question: We were really genuinely frightened by Proposition Six, and with the backlash gaining strength, we were very pessimistic. We didn't think there was any chance we could beat it. What we hoped to do was to organize to the point that when we did lose, there would be a revolt... That all hell would break lose.
answer: People are coming out, though. We met with groups in Bakersfield, Redding, a dozen people showed up in a library basement in Fresno asking for our support if they came out. Last Sunday, the Reverend of St. Mary's came out to his entire congregation...

question: We're still losing, 60 to 30. We have to take the show on the road. Call Briggs's office. Do a press release. Tell them he can pick the town, the audience, and I'll ask our supporters not to attend.
answer: Their audiences are insanely devout. We'll get killed.

question: Get me Orange County.
answer: You just have to go down to LA and guess the right things on TV and they'll pay us... You have to use your fame now while you have it. We could have nice things.

question: I don't have time to do game shows right now... This stops Jack cold.
answer: You are horrible! I have worked on this surprise for you for weeks!

question: Are you drunk right now?
answer: You are an ungrateful asshole!

question: Jack, I'll have more time soon.
answer: You're ashamed of me!

question: That's not true. I think you're smart. You're capable. No matter what your family or your father said. I believe in you... We should figure out something for you to do. I could get you a job.
answer: I'll never be good enough for you! Jack THROWS A PIECE OF POTTERY AT HARVEY. It misses, CRASHING THROUGH THE WINDOW onto the street below.

question: I'll get a broom. Harvey goes. Jack collapses into a chair. If in your statements here you say that child molestation is not an issue, why do you put out literature that hammers it home, why do you play on that myth and fear?
answer: Same thing with VD Harvey, we put out publications about VD so you can avoid it.

question: But you've even admitted that there's more molestation in the heterosexual group! So why not get rid of the heterosexual teachers? Boos from the conservative audience.
answer: We are not talking about homos... child molestation, the fact is, at least 95 percent of the people are heterosexual. If we took heterosexuals out AND homosexuals out, you know what--

question: --No child molestation... So you're saying the percentage of population is equal to the percentage of child molestation?
answer: No, no, I'm not saying that at all--

question: That's what you just said.
answer: No. I'm saying that we cannot prevent child molestation so let's cut our odds down and take out the homosexual group and keep in the heterosexual group-- Harvey laughs in disbelief at the asinine argument. Briggs looks down to his notes, lost. Harvey takes the opportunity to rip into the State Senator:

question: Hey Jack, what's wrong?
answer: Nothing. I just want to know when you'll be home.

question: You just had them pull me out of my big vote on the dog shit ordinance. Did you do this on purpose, Jack?
answer: It's poop, Harvey. Aren't I more important than poop?

question: Yes, but... I don't know when I'll be home. Maybe 6. 6:15.
answer: Fine. 6:15. Harvey hangs up. His patience is slipping. He looks up in time to see Dan heading down the hall with his briefcase.

question: Dan? How's the baby?
answer: You didn't bring up Supervisor pay raises. In fact, I heard you plan to publicly oppose them.

question: I heard you planned to vote against them too, Dan. Were you trying to set me up?
answer: (parrotting Harvey It's not a good time for me to bring it up. Politically.

question: Dan, there's a vote to approve the police desegregation settlement, give me that and I'll consider backing pay raises.
answer: I don't trade votes... unlike you, the way I was raised, we believe in right and wrong. Moral and immoral.

question: Black skin and White in your police department? Dan, even Ronald Reagan's come out against Proposition Six. You're looking more and more out of touch.
answer: If I come out against Prop Six, it's only for the invasion of State's rights issue.

question: And the potential witch hunts against you "straight people," right? Dan tries hard to come up with a cogent response. He can't. His behavior is alarming. He sets down his briefcase.
answer: You underestimate me, Milk. You're very, very wrong about me.

question: I don't know what you mean. A moment. Dan is on the verge of tears, hot angry tears. What is it, Dan? You can tell me.
answer: You don't... You can't humiliate me. And you will not demean me.

question: Put it up on the board. Harvey tries to stomach this major defeat, loss after loss. He starts reflexively tying his tie in a knot. Cleve comes up to Harvey, concerned. The whole world is watching this. This is San Francisco we're about to lose. Are you ready?
answer: I can have 15,000 people in an hour. But there's gonna be riots if this thing passes.

question: There goddamn better be.
answer: What are you telling me?

question: No sir, this is Paul. Don just gave me the phone.
answer: Paul who?

question: You talked to me on the phone a year or so ago. I'm from Minnesota... I'm in a wheelchair. REVEAL
answer: I thought you were a goner, Paul.

question: I'm sorry. I should have called. When I read in the paper that you won the Supervisor seat, I got a friend to put me on a bus to LA.
answer: Who did you know in Los Angeles?

question: Nobody. That's the uh... I just didn't want to die anymore, sir. I met your friend Don down here. I turned 18. I voted today against Prop Six... Thank you, Mr. Milk.
answer: No. You did this all by yourself.

question: I don't think I'd be alive right now without you, sir. You were right about LA. It's like gay Disney World.
answer: Then you have to see San Francisco!

question: Okay. I will. Don wanted me to um... congratulate you on what he says looks like a big win for us tonight. Congratulations Mr. Milk. Harvey turns back to the map. Jim Rivaldo is now coloring in LA county with green. On the other end of the phone, Harvey's friend in LA, Don Amador, is back on the line.
answer: I gotta go, Don. Thank you. LA by 65% put it up! Put it up! The tone in the room is changing. Jim storms up.

question: Well crap Cleve, now what are we going to do tonight?! Cover up Lady Liberty. The cameras will be coming our way. To the gay community all over this state... my message to you is... so far a lot of people joined us and rejected Proposition Six, and now we owe them something... We must destroy the myths once and for all, shatter them. We must continue to speak out... and most importantly, most importantly, every gay person must come out.
answer: What's the matter?

question: You ever heard of sore losers? Well, I'm a sore winner... I thought we were goners.
answer: I told you, I don't "do" losing.

question: I think maybe we're best with our backs to the wall. It's too quiet. I think we should march on Washington D.C. next year.
answer: Milk, you're a decent politician, a mediocre businessman, but you're a lousy gay man. Take some time off. Fifty's right around the corner. Nobody will want you after that... I can handle D.C.

question: The people voted for us, Cleve Jones.
answer: They did. There's nowhere to march tonight, Mr. Harvey Milk. Lets go back inside. Turning back, they savor the moment, like father and son walking to Castro Camera, growing ever smaller in the frame.

question: Could you give this to the Mayor for me? As soon as possible.
answer: Morning, Dan.

question: I just resigned. Congratulations. I'm sure you're pleased. Harvey doesn't know what to say. Dan's right, it does make him happy. But it's not that simple. You'll be the next President of the Board.
answer: I'm sure we could work together-- Dan walks away from Harvey. He doesn't want to hear anything Harvey has to say. Harvey watches as Dan is met in the hallway by an OFFICER from the POLICE OFFICERS ASSOCIATION.

question: Sure... Dan heads for his office. It was a major decision on Friday that I had to come... to arrive at. But since that time, people unknown to me, plus my family and friends, have come to me and stated that they want me to stay in office, that they support me... So I'm asking the Mayor to let me stay in office to serve the people...
answer: He gets dragged into a closed door meeting with the Police Officers Association, and comes out demanding his job back? What do you think they promised him? Or worse, how did they threaten him?

question: He gets dragged into a closed door meeting with the Police Officers Association, and comes out demanding his job back? What do you think they promised him? Or worse, how did they threaten him?
answer: A man has the right to change his mind. Give me some peace.

question: How many of our propositions has Dan shut down? We could finally settle this police desegregation nonsense. Cement rent control. It's his vote on this Board that stands in our way.
answer: I get it, Harvey. I've been lobbied all week. Enough.

question: Let me just remind you that you're up for re-election. If you re- appoint Dan, you lose the gay vote. They listen to me. You won't get elected dog catcher.
answer: I'll make my decision on Monday. You know what you sounded like just now? Boss Tweed or Mayor Daly.

question: Hello? REVEAL
answer: Sorry to wake you up.

question: What's wrong?
answer: I went to the opera tonight. Guess who my date was.

question: Who?
answer: Bidu Sayao herself. She was in the first Puccini I ever saw. The crowd went wild. It was like I was young again, seeing my first live opera...

question: If you go to the opera again, you should call me.
answer: Really? Scott gets out of bed, considers his words. It's intimate.

question: Yes. I'd go with you.
answer: I'd like that. Harvey is quiet, a rare moment of reflection. An unexpected tear rolls down his cheek.

question: Harvey?
answer: Look out the window, the sun's coming up.

question: It's late. You should get some sleep.
answer: I don't want to miss it.

question: Miss what?
answer: This. Harvey's single word answer means, "Life." OFF Harvey
